posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
We have these deep cycle batteries that we use for practice sessions. Rather than the “blade” type terminals that our competiton batteries have, there is just a threaded hole.

During a vigorous practice session these sometimes work loose and the increased resistance causes enough heat to melt the electrical tape.

IMG_3404 1920×2560 323 KB

IMG_3404 1920×2560 323 KB

IMG_3404 1920×2560 323 KB

Is there a way to keep these tight?   Wondering about Loctite but worried it would end up insulating the bolt from the battery.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
I think you want most of your conduction to come between the flat connector of your battery cable and the top surface of the threaded terminal. The screw will conduct some but isn’t your primary means - either way loctite may not be the right option. There’s probably some locking washer that would help under the screw head.

Honestly though what I found the most helpful in recent seasons is using more flexible battery wire. High strand count, silicone jacket, and clips relieves the strain before it ever gets back to the battery terminal. Obviously you also want to constrain your battery, but even if it’s shifting around if you can isolate the strain relief away from the terminals you should be in good shape.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
We are just copying what we’ve seen work well for other people, not sure if you have a similar ledge on your battery that would allow the clip to install

Screenshot_20251004-102119 960×531 49.9 KB

Screenshot_20251004-102119 960×531 49.9 KB

Screenshot_20251004-102119 960×531 49.9 KB

posts.name: jedgar6
posts.cooked: I feel like this could open up a market to sell prewired batteries. A lot of teams have issues with getting them right.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: This is how we are doing our new comp batteries (with grasshopper nuts). Not sure why it didn’t occur to me to try this with just a nordlock on the deep cycles.  Thanks!

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
As a general rule of thumb, for wires of the sizes used in FRC robots, bolted connections should be tightened until the wire cannot be moved or rotated with finger pressure.

Many of those terminals are a threaded piece of lead so one must be careful not to strip the threads.

posts.name: Domtech
posts.cooked:
john3928:

Rather than the “blade” type terminals that our competiton batteries have, there is just a threaded hole.

We tried out using this style a few years ago, they were PowerSonics with a m5 tapped hole. image 1200×956 66.8 KB The way we got secure connections was by loctite-ing in an alloy steel m5 setscrew and using a nyloc nut with a Belleville washer (something like McMaster part# 91477A123).

image 1200×956 66.8 KB

image 1200×956 66.8 KB

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: You could also consider nordlock washers (please don’t use normal “lock” washers!).
